section.name: Cultures of the Book:  Practices, Materials, Places

comments:
This course introduces students to literature from early modern England and America, including the making, dissemination and reading of texts. Aside from books, the class also explores other forms of writing that include walls, stone, and scrolls. Students will analyze various methods for reading and interpreting texts as well as interrelations between printing, writing, and oral. Books for this class include the Bible, Shakespeare works, Don Quixote, the New England Primer, and Ben Franklin’s autobiography.
Students described the class as a “great mix” of concrete exercises and conceptual issues, supplemented by a diverse collection of readings. However, some felt that the class lacked a “sense of community” because of its large size, which prevented meaningful discussions.
Students praised Professor Stallybrass for his accessibility outside of the classroom and found him to be passionate about the material. Moreover, the course was co-taught so they particularly enjoyed the academic dialogue between Professors Stallybrass and Chartier that took place during class. However, they felt that the class lacked focus because both professors tended to “ramble a bit.”
Students did not find the class to be particularly difficult nor did it require too much work. Some students believed that the class would benefit from meeting three times a week rather than the one three-hour seminar.

section.name: Cultures of the Book:  Practices, Materials, Places

comments:
This course introduces students to literature from early modern England and America, including the making, dissemination and reading of texts. Aside from books, the class also explores other forms of writing that include walls, stone, and scrolls. Students will analyze various methods for reading and interpreting texts as well as interrelations between printing, writing, and oral. Books for this class include the Bible, Shakespeare works, Don Quixote, the New England Primer, and Ben Franklin’s autobiography.
Students described the class as a “great mix” of concrete exercises and conceptual issues, supplemented by a diverse collection of readings. However, some felt that the class lacked a “sense of community” because of its large size, which prevented meaningful discussions.
The course was co-taught and students particularly enjoyed the academic dialogue between Professors Stallybrass and Chartier that took place during class. However, they felt that the class lacked focus because both professors tended to “ramble a bit.” Students also found that Professor Chartier’s accent made him hard to understand and tended to distract from the lecture material.
Students did not find the class to be particularly difficult nor did it require too much work. Some students also believed that the class would benefit from meeting three times a week rather than the one three-hour seminar.
